title: How can bacteria be helpful to humans? - Quora

response.answer_text: On and inside the human body, bacteria create huge benefits, most of which are essential for life. For example in the digestive system , they help us break down food, like plant fibers or milk, that we're not so good a handling ourselves. Bacteria in the digestive system also supply us with needed vitamins like biotin and vitamin K, and are our primary source for some of these nutrients. Experiments done on guinea pigs have shown that animals raised in a sterile environment without any bacteria are malnourished and die young. Outside the body, the forest of bacteria on the skin (almost 200 separate species on a normal person) dominates the environment of the skin and its resources, keeping other bacteria from being able to establish a foothold. And in or out, exposure to bacteria has been shown to be an important part of the development of our immune systems . Exposure to bacteria, both benign and harmful, is what primes the immune system to respond to pathogenic invaders later in life. Research published in the New England Journal of Medicine, for instance, has also shown that children who are sheltered from bacteria have a higher chance of developing asthma and allergies. This is not to say beneficial bacteria can't also be dangerous. Usually, helpful bacteria and harmful bacteria are mutually exclusive. But there is a overlap, notably in the bacteria that inhabit the body. Staph bacteria is a good example, because it's all over our skin. A colony of Staphylococcus aureus living on the arm might be plugging along, crowding out intruders without harming the body, but if you get a cut or your immune system is compromised , those bacteria can run amok causing an infection. The number of bacterial cells in the body is commonly estimated at 10 times the number of human cells. That's caused a lot of scientists to describe us as more bacteria than human. It's a little creepy, but it helps you visualize how large a role these organisms play.

Without bacteria, most other, if not all, life forms could not exist. Bacteria are the ultimate recyclers. In a single teaspoon of soil, over a billion bacteria can be found. Plants need nitrogen for growth and for proteins. But they can't use nitrogen in air. Soil bacteria though, through their own cellular metabolism can use gasous nitrogen converting to nitrates and nitrites as part of their waste, forms which can then be absorbed by plant roots. Other bacteria (and fungi) also break down organic matter (dead plants and animals) into forms absorbed by plant roots. Thus bacteria aid in converting abiotic matter into biotic forms. Plants feed herbivores and omnivores and in turn, other omnivores and carnivores eat those animals. Without bacteria, the wastes produced by animals and the bodies of dead animals, from tiny nematodes to insects to larger animals would remain intact. Bacteria recycles all this. Besides yogurt and keffir mentioned by John J. Peloquin, bacteria are responsible for the fermentation of many foods from sauerkraut to certain soy sauces to black tea and much more. Ruminants (such as cows) with multiple stomach chambers are able to break down indigestible cellulose into absorbable carbohydrates through the action of their gut bacteria. Because the many billions of bacteria in their gut have a very short lifespan, the dead bacterial cells are an invaluable source of protein for ruminants. In biotechnology, bacteria are used to produce human insulin and human growth factors as well as antibiotics. I remember how excited the medical world was able to offer diabetics actual human insulin. The human insulin comes from the gene that produces insulin in humans, which has been spliced into a bacterial genome using recombinant DNA technology. The bacterium produces the insulin, which is then purified for human use. Before there was genetically engineered human insulin, diabetics were given insulin extracted from pig pancreases, which was similar to, but not exactly like, human insulin. Because it was not exactly like human insulin, the pig insulin caused complications in some diabetic patients. from  10.2 Biotechnology in Medicine and Agriculture Too often people think of the negative aspects when they hear the word bacteria but bacteria do a huge amount of good for our world. The disease causing bacteria, while seemingly to be a large number, are very few compared to bacteria that benefit life.

Some species of bacteria live in the human intestines where they help in digestion of food by releasing certain components. They also produce some vitamins which are helpful for the human body. E. coli is the specie which resides in the digestive tract of humans and help in breaking down the lactose. The new born babies do not suffer or have fewer chances of suffering from diarrhea if they are administered with the bacteria Lactobacillus reuteri or Bifidobacterium. The process of fermentation takes place with the help of bacteria. If the milk is fermented and contains live bacteria Lactobacillus casei, it removes the harmful bacteria Helicobacter pylori from children's body. Similarly, Saccharomyces boulardii also helps to reduce the risk of antibiotic associated diarrhea from the children. Some bacterial species live on our skin and protect it from getting fungal infections. If the DNA molecule undergoes some internal damage in its structure or function, six strains or bacteria help to reduce the damage. It can be said that human body is just like a home to bacteria. They live within almost every part of the body as well as outside the body. There are many bacteria which live inside mouth, throat, nose and intestines and perform various useful functions. They also do not let the harmful microorganisms live inside or on the human body and in return provide benefit to the human body. Various species of bacteria live in the humans' intestine and work with the immune system to protect the body against various diseases. Some intestinal bacteria are able to produce Vitamin A and K. the main function of bacteria residing in the stomach is to maintain the ph and acidity level in the stomach. From https://www.biotecharticles.com/Biology-Article/Beneficial-and-Harmful-Bacteria-312.html

Bacteria are economically important, as these micro organisms are used by humans for myriad purposes. These are as follows : Some breads and dough are made to rise by fermentation, with a leaven that consists of bacteria, often combined with yeasts.The milk-souring bacterium Lactobacillus is used to make yogurt and cheese. Bacteria are used, too, to form organic acids in pickles and vinegar.Bacteria are extensively used in the chemical manufacturing of ethanol, acetone, organic acid, enzymes, and perfumes. In the chemical industry, bacteria are most important in the production of pharmaceuticals.Bacteria play many roles in agriculture from bio-degradation to food production. Bacteria are often employed in the dairy industry for making yogurt, ripening cheese and giving certain dairy products a specific aroma. Bacteria including Bacillus aceti convert wine or beer into vinegar easily.Using biotechnology techniques, or biomedical technology bacteria can also be bio-engineered for the production of therapeutic proteins.The Escherichia coli (E-coli) that lives in the human large intestine synthesizes vitamin B and releases it for human use. Similarly, Clostridium butyclicum is used for commercial preparation of riboflavin(vit. B2), and vitamin B & vitamin K.Bacteria can also be used in the place of pesticides in biological pest control. This commonly uses Bacillus thuringiensis (also called BT), a Gram-positive, soil-dwelling bacterium. Because of their specificity, these pesticides are regarded as environment friendly, with little or no effect on humans, wildlife, pollinators, and most other beneficial insects.The bacteria present in the stomach of cattle helps in the digestion of cellulose.Bacteria are used to separate fibers of jute, hemp and flax in the process of fiber retting.With the aid of gene therapy, transfer of normal genes to human cells can also be engineered.

We need bacteria to protect us. Many/most of the commensal bacteria we carry act as immune system stimulants early in life. Repeated research using murine models show that “sterile” born and raised mouse pups have reduced immunity later in life and have increased incidence of autoimmunity when compared to pups born in a “normal” environment. Human studies mirror this. The increasing use of fecal transplantation has helped patients restore immune function and reduce infection. This is especially important in view of the overuse of antimicrobial drugs. Clostridium difficile is a spore forming anaerobe that easily survives antimicrobial regimens and causes pseudomembranous colitis, a serious life threatening infection in the very and young and very old. Many of our commensal MOs occupy environmental niches that inhibit growth of pathogenic bacteria, espcially in the GI tract and skin. Lactobacilli produces acids in the GI and vaginal tract. Various Gram negatives process Vitamin K which is needed for coagulation.

How are bacteria beneficial to us? I can think of a few ways… Some bacteria, such as Escherichia coli, produce metabolic byproducts that are actually useful or even beneficial to us. E. coli produces vitamin K, our major source of the vitamin, in case you didn’t know.Bacteria tend to outcompete parasites and other pathogens for space. And if the pathogens can’t find a place to reside, they can’t infect the host.Some bacteria produce bacteriocins, which restrict or kill bacteria of similar species. So the E. coli in your gut probably killed the E. coli you ingested when you ate that meat that was not prepared properly first.An argument can be made that gut flora actually teaches the immune system to recognize pathogenic bacteria, and that teaching helps you to fight off infections even faster. So the E. coli in your gut that you very likely got either from birth or breast milk taught your immune system to recognize E. coli, and as soon as it enters your body from an external source your immune system recognizes and attacks it with a much stronger immune system than if it were the first infection.I’m just sticking to inside the host’s body. There are other uses for bacteria outside of the host’s body as well, such as understanding antibiotic resistance and getting to explore virus replication. That may sound useless to you, but these things must be done to tackle bacterial and viral infections efficiently and with the least damage done to the host.

Bacteria are very versatile and diverse groups of micro-organisms. Most of them are bad as they causes diseases commonly known as pathogens. But some group of bacteria are very good and beneficial not only to the humans but the environment in every aspect. 1. Do you know that human guts and intestines are the natural habitat for bacterial species. There is common term in biology for that “ human microbiota” - it is the aggregate of microorganism that lives in the human tissue and bio-fluids which includes skin, mammary glands, uterus, ovarian follicles, saliva, oral mucosa and gastrointestinal tracts. These aggregates includes bacteria fungi protists and viruses, but here we talked about only bacteria. These bacteria are responsible for fortifying the immune system. They help in digestive system of the humans, safeguards to our skins. 2. They are efficient recyclers ; They are responsible for the decomposition of organic matter in soils and oceans. Some of bacterial groups can even chelate heavy metals from the soil and protect the environment from heavy metal contamination. 3. Plants and animals are not able to uptake the nitrogen without the help of bacteria. Some species of soil bacteria and cyanobacteria play an indispensable role in fixing the atmospheric nitrogen into ammonium ions or nitrate ions which are the precursors of amino acids and nucleic acids. 4. They have economical importance ; Bacteria are economically important too, as they are the involved in the production of cheese, yoghurt, vinegar, antibiotics production, sewage treatment plants, production of biofuels and bio-plastics. References: https://www.livescience.com/32761-good-bacteria-boost-immune-system.html https://www.toppr.com/bytes/humans-and-bacteria/ https://www.sciencelearn.org.nz/resources/588-bacteria-good-bad-and-ugly

Perhaps the most important function of bacteria in the body is that of your gut bacteria.  Your gut bacteria (also known as your gut microbiota) is made up of the ecosystem inside of your large intestine.  There are over 1000 species of bacteria that can be found in your large intestine.  Everyone shares 1/3 of their gut bacteria with most people on Earth, but 2/3 of our gut bacteria is unique to us.  This bacteria allows us to digest foods that our own digestive systems cannot (beans, for example) and also plays a role in immune regulation and vitamin production.   Our gut microbiota develops from after we are born to around the age of three and continues to develop throughout our lives.  Gut bacteria is formed as a result of everything we eat.  Babies start growing their microbiota from their mother's breast milk, and throughout their lives, everything that spends time in their intestine leaves some bacteria behind.  Thus, people who eat different foods have different gut bacteria.  Your gut bacteria is damaged by antibiotics, which is why doctors hesitate to prescribe too many antibiotics in a short period of time.  On the other hand, if you're interested in improving the state of your gut bacteria, it would be good to consume probiotics in the form of supplements or foods like yogurt or sauerkraut.   When people have severe issues with their gut bacteria, they may be advised to undergo a fecal transplant, which, like it sounds, is when the fecal matter (poop) of a healthy person is transferred into the large intestine of a sick person with the objective of introducing a healthy gut microbiota into an unhealthy system. That's all I know about it, hope this interested you!

Bacteria are diverse in nature and are widely distributed around us, bring found almost everywhere. They are present in still ponds and ditches, in running streams rivers, in seawater, in soil, in air, in foods, in petroleum oil from deeply seated regions, in rubbish and manure heaps, in decaying organic matter of all kinds, on body surface, in body cavities and in the intestinal tracts of man and animals. Those who are not familiar with the elementary rudiments of bacteriology have an erroneous concept of the role of bacteria in nature - that the some purpose of bacteria in this earth is to cause illness to humans. Plants and animals owe their existence to the fertility of the soil, and this in turn depends upon the activity of the soil population. Posts absorb their nutrients from the soil in the form of minerals. They cannot utilise organic compounds such as fat, carbohydrates and proteins. The soul soil organisms attack the human and animal carcasses and mineralise the organic constituents, making them available to plants. A few species of soul bacteria are capable of invading the roots of certain plays, where they take free nitrogen from the air and convert it into organic compounds which ate utilized btly plants. The bacteria, in torn, derive their nutrients from the sap of the plants. This may be cited as an excellent example of a symbiotic relationship occuring in nature between 2 different species. Bacteria are necessary for disposal of sewage. The convert the insoluble proteins, fats and cellulose into soluble, odourless compounds. The souring of milk is the result of bacterial action. This is the first step in the preparation of butter. Various types of industrial fermentations are produced by the action of bacteria. Butyric acid, acetone, butyl alcohol, lactic acid and propionic acid are produced by bacterial action.

1.) They are a source of antibiotics. (See Streptomyces and Bacillus species.) 2.) The bacteria associated with your body (i.e., the microbiome) carry out microbial antagonism. This means they keep “bad microbes” from over growing on and in your body. 3.) Some bacteria are nitrogen fixers. This means they convert atmospheric nitrogen into a usable form for other organisms, including us. (See Rhizobium.) 4.) Some of the bacteria in your gut (e.g., E. coli) are responsible for producing vitamin K for you. Vitamin K is nicknamed the “clotting vitamin,” because you can’t make a blood clot without it. *5.) Just for good measure - the gut bacteria also produce B vitamins, too! These are important for energy. I hope this answers your question. These microbes are pretty important!

There are so many examples that can describe how bacteria can be helpful. Bacteria in the intestinal tract helps the body to digest food.The production of several foods, such as cheeses, sausage and sauerkraut, depend upon bacteria or fermenting bacteria in order to reach their finished states.Harmless bacteria is used to treat some bacterial infections in the human body by interfering with the colonization of the harmful bacteria.Hydrocarbon-oxidizing bacterias aid in the decomposition of petroleum, and they are used by industry when cleaning oil spills.

Bacteria in the intestinal tract helps the body to digest food. The production of several foods, such as cheeses, sausage and sauerkraut, depend upon bacteria or fermenting bacteria in order to reach their finished states. Harmless bacteria is used to treat some bacterial infections in the human body by interfering with the colonization of the harmful bacteria. Hydrocarbon-oxidizing bacterias aid in the decomposition of petroleum, and they are used by industry when cleaning oil spills.

We could not live without bacteria. The ways they are helpful is beyond describing and enumerating. But I'll give you a few examples. In our guts, certain bacteria (Bacteroides) are essential in the development of our immune systems. Bacteria in our guts and elsewhere produce vitamin K- an essential clotting factor. Lactic acid and other bacteria make cheese what it is and produce youghurt, kefir etc. Bacteria produce antibiotics and are used in biotechnology to produce useful recominant proteins. These are just a few of the helpful things they do.

A variety of microbes exists throughout the human body and have fundamental role in human health. Studies have revealed that human microbiome of every healthy individual differs remarkably in the matter of different varieties of microbes. In the body, these microbes are present in different parts such as skin, nasal cavity, oral cavity, gut and vagina and therefore stay in different habitats. Some microbes that colonize humans are commensal, whereas others have a mutualistic relationship with the host. These interactions are important for human to grow and stay healthy. Microbiome is an essential component of immunity and a functional entity that influences metabolism and modulates drug interactions. It has been known since long time that microorganisms in the human body play an important role in maintaining human health.

Very, very few make us ill. The vast majority shapes all ecosystems by degrading nutrients and producing metabolites. Some of the live within us, particularly our gut, and make nutrients (e.g. Vitamin K) for us that can shape anything from our own metabolism to our mental health. Many protect us from bad infections by outcompeting pathogens at sites where we are vulnerable. We're far from understanding what exactly happens mechanistically in many cases but they seem to be involved in loads of things. Tldr: SUPER IMPORTANT FOR ALL SORTS OF STUFF

From an industrial perspective, bacteria have many positive uses such as producing food ingredients, useful chemicals and creating energy. Currently, the world of animal production is reducing antibiotic usage by using probiotic bacteria (known as Direct Fed Microbials) as antibiotic alternatives. Bacteria and other microbes are used everyday to breakdown wastes and harmful chemicals in wastewater, landfills, and bio-remediation applications. Just recently, our company just filed a patent for a bacterial formulation with an extended shelf life that breaks down plastics in landfills. Further, newly isolated bacteria are minded regularly for new medicinal properties. In summary, bacteria can help to Feed, Clean and Save the World.

Many many many ways.... LAB - these are called lacto bacillus found commonly in  milk products and good for gut.Scp- single cell protein, natural protein supplenent.For making alchoholic beverages, lot of yeast strains are used.Food fermentaion is done by microbes.Bio fuels and bio gas are due to effect of microbes.Genetically engineered microbes are being used to clean oil spills in oceans.Many useful microbes retain soil fertility.Google and find tons of info.

The list is quite long so I’ll limit it to the first five that come to mind: they produce vitamin K in our gut, this is a necessary component of our clotting mechanismwe utilize them for natural fermentation products such as yogurtwe have altered their genetics to produce products such as insulin for diabeticsthey help decompose materials which have died. Without them and fungi we wouldn't be able to recycle nutrientsthe photosynthetic varieties utilize carbon dioxide and release oxygen, people have a tendency to think of plants only when discussing photosynthesis and ignore the bacterial contributionThere’s a start if anyone wishes to contribute more have at it.

Answer is; in more than one way viz. 1. as a pro-biotic (friendly bacteria) to replace intestinal flora “killed off” by antibiotics. 2. as part of a mechanism to improve soil health (depleted by us through mismanaged fertigation - excess fertilizer without application of carbon based products and composting). 3. by combating pathogens (diseases found in crops) in a natural way. All this has, of course, to be caried out in combination with a well balanced nutritional program in combination with carbon based products where the crop immune system is boosted via other mechanisms.

Read this book: I Contain Multitudes: The Microbes Within Us and a Grander View of Life It is enlightening. !0% of our body is microbes (bacterias, viruses and fungi) that are living in us since we became multicellular (I think ~800million yer ago). They are essential to our well being and development. Bad bugs are just a tiny-tiny minority! You get autoimmune diseases and allergies because we are messing around with antibiotics, etc…

There are numerous answers to this, depending on your perspective: bacteria on our skin, and in our bodies help protect us from other disease-causing bacteriabacteria in our gut help us to digest food and make certain vitaminsbacteria help decompose dead organisms, otherwise corpses would litter the landscapegenetically engineered bacteria make useful products for us, eg. insulin, or are used to clean up oil spillsthe mitochondria in our cells are the descendants of symbiotic bacteria, and produce energy for us by breaking down sugarsphotosynthetic bacteria are responsible for producing most of the oxygen in our atmosphere

Though many bacteria are harmful to mankind,some bacteria are used to enhance our day to day life in the fields of medicine,food ,agriculture . Lactic acid bacteria:eg-lactobacillus It used to make curd from milk.the bacteria releases some enzymes which breaks the milk proteins partially and coagulate milk into curd. Lactic acid bacteria also plays a very important role in our stomach to increase the capacity of vitamin B12. There are many bacteria which are used in the preparation of cheese E-coli:this bacteria is used to produce humulin harmone which is similar to human insulin. Cynabacteria: this bacteria is present in paddy fields and helps the plant in development.

Stool transplant. Sounds crazy, right? But yes it is done. Also known as “faecal microbiota transplant” is done in cases of Clostridium difficle infection (pseudomembranous colitis) and also in Irritable bowel syndrome. The mechanism of its action is thought to be replacement of pathogenic microorganisms by the commensal organisms (harmless rather useful) of the bowel present in stools.Insulin production. Humanised insulin also called humulin is produced in Escherichia coli using r-DNA technology. This produces ample of insulin that is pure and in less time.

There are millions of bacteria within our body, specially in the digestive system. These microorganism help us asimilate food and protect us from the bad guys. There is an interesting suggestion about the mitocondrias in eukaryotic cells. It is said in the past the mitocondrias was a bacteria. The bacteria entered through the cell as a host and provides it with energy. Through millions of year of evolution the bacteria ended up being a part of the cell. This endosymbiotic theory is reasonable due to multiples facts such as to mitocondrias has it own DNA and the organelle behavior itself is similar to a bacteria etc.

The guys of Kingdom Monera or Bacteria as we know them, have numerous uses They are invaluable in the production of fermented food products such as curd, cheese, sauerkraut, yoghurt, buttermilk etc.They are important in the tanning of leather.Used in the designing and preparation of numerous antibiotics such as Streptomycin.Bacteria in human gut produces Vitamin K.I could go on and on about the benefits of bacteria but then that would make this answer needlessly wrong. Not all of them cause diseases :)

Bacteria can be bemeficial in different ways, for example, in the Biotechnology industry, they can be used to make human insulin. Here’s how it’s done: First, a plasmid is taken from a single bacterium, and it is cut with enzymes, so it looks like a ‘C’.Next, human insulin is taken and is attached to the ‘sticky ends’ of the cut plasmid using enzymes.The bacteria containing the human insulin is allowed to reproduce, and hence, artificial insulin is produced.Bacteria can also be beneficial to us in our bodies, for example the bacteria living in our gut.

This is more fully discussed in a biology text. But simply some are decomposes, others fix nitrogen in the soil, others cause disease, some foods like cheese and yogurt are made with bacterial action, they are important in making some drugs, retting if flax ( making linen), and genetic engineering. They are not all bad guys.

The first thing that comes to my mind is the bacterial flora that colonize our intestines. These bacteria are very important for our health. They help us digest and absorb nutrients from the food we eat. They help other bacteria breakdown sugars and they also ferment certain carbohydrates that would otherwise be indigestible.

There are dozens of examples. See my book:Biofilms & Dead Zones: The Microbe-Environment Connection: How Unseen Life Influences the World Around Us: David M. Carlberg PH. D.: 9781410749918: Amazon.com: Books

Decomposes organic matter into humus eg Leuconostoc Fermentation process of silages milk and alcohol eg Lactobacillus Digestion of cellulose by provision of enzymes cellulase in intestine of non ruminants Nitrogen fixation in root nodules of legumes eg Rhizobium and free living bacteria such as Nitrosomonas bacteria

Bacteria are mostly friends and essential for our life, barring a few. For details you may read my presentation:https://www.researchgate.net/publication/264165886_Emergence_of_antimicrobial_drug_resistance_is_mandatory_for_life_on_the_earth & Antimicrobial drug use and its implications

Fecal Transplant. When someone has a Clostridium Difficile infection that is not responding to antibiotics, doctors will use the stool of a healthy individual to re-seed the colon of the sick person. It can be a life saving treatment for at-risk populations. http://thefecaltransplantfoundation.org/what-is-fecal-transplant/
Economic importance of bacteria Antibiotic:- streptomycin is prepared from staphylococcusFor making curd:- milk convert into curd through a bacteria LAB lactic acid bacteria

While there are certainly bacteria that helps us live, one notable, but forgotten example of good bacteria is Cyanobacteria. They help provide oxygen for us, so they aren’t just good, they’re necessary
